Just for clarity let's remember the Texas tower shootings were done mostly with a bolt action rifle (some with a pump shotgun), as was the JFK assassination, RFK was killed with a .22 caliber revolver and MLK with a pump action hunting rifle. Wallace was paralyzed by a bullet from a revolver and Reagan was shot by a .22 caliber revolver. Finally, John Lennon was killed with a .38 caliber revolver. What do all these guns have in common? None are semi-automatic, none have high capacity magazines, none are assault weapons, and none would be banned under almost any of the current proposed gun control legislation.

SR: what these all have in common( other than the Texas tower, where position was more important than weapon) is there was number of victims. The Reagan shooting an exception was committed in front of one of the most highly thought of and best armed security details in the world.
No one expects shootings to stop, right now our only hope is to limit the damage.

Tim, we allow the proliferation of dangerous weapons because there are some who are unable to defend themselves without them.

Two rapists tried to break into our apartment when I was out of town. At 2AM, they kicked open the fence around the front door. They then began to kick open the front door. My wife turned on the light in the living room, yelling that she was calling 911. The thugs laughed, and said they'd be in and gone well before the cops got there. They then began to tell my wfe exactly what they would do to here once they got in.

My terrified wife realized they were right, so she ran to the bedroom and got the pistol we had, a semi-automatic Colt 1911. She smacked the pistol on the window, telling them they would be eating that if they came through the door.

The cowards ran like the animals they are.

So, the dangerous weapon saved a 4'11", 100 lb woman from two 6' plus, 200 lb plus animals who were hell bent on attacking her. If we could have avoided the incident, we most certainly would. But given that it happened, I'm glad she had a "dangerous weapon" to defend herself.

'The assertion on Friday by Wayne LaPierre, the vice president of the National Rifle Association, that “the only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun” was as much a sales pitch as it was a restatement of the organization’s perverse philosophy.'

LaPierre's statement reminds me of an inane bumper sticker, with the difference that his Dirty Harry approach is one which is swallowed by unstable people who see a bogey man around every corner.

Years ago, I had a young friend in his early twenties, who was immature and prone to anger. One day as he rode his motorcycle through a neighborhood, someone yelled at insult at him. He turned around, went back and confronted the stunned man with his newly acquired handgun. The way he told the story, if the man had provoked him further, he would have shot him.

Why are we allowing this proliferation of dangerous weapons, knowing full well that when some people become angry or agitated, they are likely to use them.

Perp/Mac has a point, but there are a few other African-Americans in the NHL. Dustin Byfuglien is from Minnesota and won the Cup with Chicago. He's a Captain now in Winnipeg. Buff scored 11 goals and had 6 assists in that Cup run. The Playoffs MVP Jonathan Toews had more points, but fewer goals. He has a slapshot a few points over 100mph.

As Klein noted, Buff is the closest thing to a big star. Wayne Simmonds (a Canadian) is one of several other well-known black players in the NHL, and he's a star now.

Emerson Etem (Anaheim's late 1st round draft pick) is from Anaheim/ Los Angeles. He was a star in the Western Hockey League and could have been drafted higher.

Canada is part of North America, no? I have never gotten the insistence on the construct "African-American" anyway. I have good friends who are from Haiti and Jamaica. Because their skins are black, they are often referred to as "African-American," but you've got to go back a long, long way in either case to find the "African" link. If you agree with the anthropological research of the Leakeys, all humanity originated in East Africa and, hence, we are ALL "African-American."

Bob, where were you when the players agreed to the owners' revenue demands? In fact, the only thing that *allegedly* separates the two sides is the owners' demand that all contracts over five years' duration be cancelled, and the players counter that they be honored, or at least, reworked into the five year or less format. The players have made literally dozens of proposals, some quite imaginative and smart, during the course of "negotiations." The owners and Bettman have rejected 100% of them, and now have the gall to accuse the players of negotiating in bad faith.
The main problem with your argument is the assumption that ten owners will leave the league willingly. Think of how hard owners and fans worked to keep hockey alive in places like Buffalo and Pittsburgh. And think of the cushy giveaways to the Coyotes by Glendale, AZ. I think Chuckles Wang wants out, but he has the rich man's assumption that he should be made whole for the money he has lost owning the Islanders. As long as not one dime of the comes from my tax dollars, I'm OK with that, and I'm more than OK with an NHL without Wang. As for contract length, it was Wang who started the trend by negotiating a 15 year deal with Rick DiPietro behind his GM's back. Don't forget how the Devils tried to circumvent the cap by structuring Ilya Kovalchuk's deal over 17 years, and even after Bettman voided it, they are STILL way longer than 5 years. Owners entirely created the lone remaining stumbling block. That's suspicious

The NHL labor impasse is the fault of the players mindful, of course, that the owners have certainly made missteps in negotiation strategy and are represented by a person whose public persona that is difficult to like.

Climbing average player salaries and the expansion of the number of player jobs — both really positive developments for the players — are the result directly and indirectly of the NHL’s expansion strategy which enabled a television contract, meager as it may by comparison to other sports, and widening popularity of hockey. The trade-off is cost containment — that’s what the owners want — particularly since so many of the sunbelt teams, central to the expansion strategy, are hemorrhaging. Reasonable cost containment allows for both rising salaries and more jobs for players, whereas contraction, (the inevitable result of no cost containment), will ultimately reduce jobs and probably also salaries.

The decision to hire Fehr is understandable but it also is a reflection of the players not understanding that the financial underpinnings of their sport are very different from baseball and football. The owners keep walking away from negotiations after NHLPA proposals not because this is a tactic or because they "are childish" but because the financial imperatives bearing down on the sport dictate their position. They have to hit their numbers or there is no point in discussing anything. The business of NHL hockey is broken. The players are in a fog about this.

I inject into myself limited doses NFL, NBA and college sports to get me through the baseball off-season; why would I need a sport with teams that actually pay large sums of money to a guy whose sole purpose is to beat the crap out of a guy on an opposing team?  And, that's usually the opponent who is paid for the same reason.
